page.title: 11LANGUAGE AT SANDHEAD
page.content: by Neil Stevenson aged 9 Sometimes we say " di ya ken " , which means DO YOU KNOW; or " gi me twa ", for GIVE ME TWO. Sometimes Robert Oliver says " It's inalow the desk " meaning IT'S BENEATH THE DESK. If someone is eating sweets and offers you " yin " they are asking if you want ONE; their " dug " is their DOG just as their " coo " is their COW. Sometimes people will build a high " wa ", or WALL, to " kep oot ", meaning KEEP OUT, other " kyes or beasts ", again being COWS. But these " ana " ARE NOT " ah " ALL the Scots words we use " cos " BECAUSE we say " fitba " for FOOTBALL and " nicht " for NIGHT; while a person who is very solemn or serious is sayed to be " an awfy dour biddy ". Sometimes we forget when we are doing our reading and we use a Scots word. Our teacher laughs.
